Description: Mould-made small scarab in glazed composition; back simply indicated with basic lines for clypeus, prothorax and elytra; at side, legs rather well-modelled with undercut triangle; underside decorated representation of a scorpion with sting curved round to the left; pierced lengthwise; glaze rubbed off; pale yellow core; surface worn.
Curator's comments: Scorpion is a relatively common theme on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the 'Scarab Factory' in Naukratis (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). They were found at Naukratis itself (Petrie 1886, pl. 37, 8-10; see also BM 1886,0401.1606, Paris, Louvre Museum E8056 bis. 2 and Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 86.694) and in many sites across the Mediterranean area (Gorton 1996, 100, type XXVIIIA, subtype A196-203). Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implication for the chronology of the site. How helpful are they in confirming its nature as a manufacturing and trading centre?', in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 10)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.068) (phase 3)
